## Project Summary Description

The project aims to introduce fuel-efficient improved cookstoves in Gambia to mitigate environmental impact and improve living conditions. Below is a concise overview of the key aspects of the project:

### Technologies/Measures Implemented
The project focuses on the distribution of fuel-efficient improved cookstoves in Gambia. These cookstoves are specially designed to burn wood more efficiently, thereby reducing health hazards associated with traditional cooking methods and combating deforestation.

### Location of the Project
The project is situated in Jabisa village, located within the Lower River Division, Jerra central district, in the Republic of Gambia.

### Expected GHG Emission Reductions or Carbon Dioxide Removals
By replacing traditional open fire cooking methods with fuel-efficient improved cookstoves, the project is expected to generate significant GHG emission reductions. The estimated total reduction in greenhouse gas emissions over a 10-year period is projected to be 10,160,672 tCO2e.

### Scenario Existing Prior to Project Implementation
Before the implementation of the project, the target population relied on inefficient three-stone fires or conventional cooking systems that lacked improved combustion air supply mechanisms and flue gas ventilation systems.

### Estimate of Annual Average and Total Reductions and Removals
The project anticipates an average annual reduction of 1,016,067 tCO2e in greenhouse gas emissions. Over the 10-year crediting period, the total reduction is estimated to reach 10,160,672 tCO2e, showcasing the significant impact of the project on carbon dioxide removal and emission reductions.

This project not only addresses environmental concerns but also contributes to the well-being of the community by promoting sustainable practices and reducing health risks associated with traditional cooking methods.

# Monitoring Plan

## Introduction

The Monitoring Plan outlines the systematic approach for obtaining, recording, compiling, and analyzing the monitored data and parameters as detailed in Section 5.2 (Data and Parameters Monitored). This plan ensures the accurate collection and management of data related to the project's environmental impact.

## Methods for Measuring and Monitoring

The methods for measuring and monitoring involve conducting monitoring surveys to track the number of project devices in operation during specific years. Sampling standards are utilized to determine sample sizes, and monitoring activities are scheduled to occur at least once every two years. Calibration procedures for monitoring equipment are established to maintain accuracy and reliability.

## Organizational Structure and Responsibilities

The project proponent will oversee and manage each project implementer, providing guidance in implementing the monitoring plan's elements. Responsibilities include conducting periodic audits and surveillance of the stoves to ensure compliance with monitoring protocols. The organizational structure ensures clear lines of communication and accountability.

## Procedures for Internal Auditing and QA/QC

Internal auditing and quality assurance procedures encompass various aspects, including data collection, spot checks of Improved Cooking Stoves (ICS), sample plans for monitoring surveys, data quality checks, consistency and duplication checks, monitoring reporting, and verifying stove manufacturing adherence to fixed design specifications. These procedures are essential for maintaining data integrity.

## Handling Non-conformances with Validated Monitoring Plan

In the event of non-conformances with the validated monitoring plan, procedures are in place to address issues promptly. Field personnel are required to review, understand, and adhere to the monitoring plan procedures. Documentation of out-of-population cases, refusals, and other non-response sources is mandatory. A quality control and assurance strategy is documented to maintain the plan's integrity.

## Sampling Approaches and Procedures

Simple Random Sampling is employed for monitored parameters, with sample sizes determined to achieve a 90/10 confidence/precision level. Sampling sites serve as primary sampling units, with monitoring conducted at least once every two years. Quality assurance and quality control procedures are integrated into the sampling approach to ensure data accuracy and reliability.

## GHG Data Collection and Management System

A line diagram illustrating the GHG data collection and management system will be included to provide a visual representation of the processes involved in monitoring, recording, and analyzing data related to greenhouse gas emissions.

By adhering to the Monitoring Plan and following the outlined procedures, the project will maintain transparency, accuracy, and reliability in monitoring its environmental impact.
